item.title: Unicoherence in Locales
item.description: arXiv:2510.24426v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: In this paper, we generalize the concept of unicoherence to the context of frames. Unicoherence, originally introduced by Kuratowski, is a connectedness property that is well studied in classical topology and used to detect holes of a space. We extend the notion of unicoherence to locales and we then investigate its properties. In particular, we prove that many of the known characterizations of unicoherence for topological spaces extend to the setting of locales. Some of these characterizations interestingly involve separation properties for locales.
item.dc:creator: Elena Caviglia, Luca Mesiti, Cerene Rathilal

item.title: Injective envelopes of $C^*$-algebras as maximal rigid multiplier covers
item.description: arXiv:2510.24441v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: We present a noncommutative analogue of B{\l}aszczyk's elegant two-step construction of the Gleason cover: \emph{first maximise irreducibility, then compactify}. The key insight is that extremal disconnectedness emerges naturally from a maximality principle rather than being imposed by hand. Fixing a faithful embedding of a $C^*$-algebra $A$ into a product $\prod_i \mathcal B(H_i)$ of concrete factors, we introduce the notion of \emph{$A$-carrier ideals}: closed two-sided ideals $J\lhd \prod_i \mathcal B(H_i)$ generated by $A$ as a~bimodule and show via the Kuratowski--Zorn lemma that there exists a \emph{maximal $A$-irreducible} such ideal $J_{\max}$. Here irreducibility means that no proper quotient of $J_{\max}$ allows $A$ to embed completely isometrically into its multiplier algebra. We prove that the canonical inclusion $A\hookrightarrow M(J_{\max})$ is both \emph{rigid} (any completely positive map fixing $A$ is the identity) and \emph{essential} (no non-trivial quotient preserves $A$ isometrically), the two defining properties of Hamana's injective envelope. This yields the identification \[ I(A)\ \cong\ M(J_{\max}) \] canonically over $A$, realising the injective envelope as a single multiplier algebra. In the commutative case $A=C(X)$ we recover B{\l}aszczyk's picture: starting from a maximal regular refinement $(X,T^\ast)$ with irreducible identity map, the Gleason space is $G(X)=\beta(X,T^\ast)$ and $I(C(X))\cong C(G(X))\cong M(C_0(U))$ for any dense open $U\subseteq G(X)$. The paradigm \emph{maximise first, then compactify} thus provides a unified conceptual framework for both the topological and operator-algebraic versions.
item.dc:creator: Tomasz Kania
